content: hey welcome to the DMS craft I'm PM Scotty I'm sitting here at my painting
bench and today I wanted to show you a painting technique that I'm going to do
the player characters come across this village has been attacked and there's
still some smoldering built cottages around and I want to simulate that with
this paint job on this terrain so we'll get to that and I'll show you how I do
that so what you'll notice here is I have a
burned-out husk of a building and a base painted it black and but one thing
you'll notice is its 3d it's not flat like the other train sometimes I do do
this and since it's so destroyed it's not going to struck the play area that
much it's not going to be around the whole hilarious play area so I made this
like more of a 3d piece so this was a former cottage that burned down and
basically what I did is I just made a base of cardboard and then I made walls
out of cardboard and just did them in the shape of the cottage and then what I
also did was I took small pieces of wood I used stir stick coffee stir sticks
which stir sticks but you could use other thin pieces of wood like balsa
wood or bass wood and I just broke them off and jab them into the into the
cardboard so they're kind of popping out and giving looking like the structures
collapsed I also put some on the base I glued some to the base I glued some
flocking and some of the basket strips to the base now keep in mind when you
make stuff like this you don't want to pile the rubble up too high because then
the figures won't be able to move around easily they'll keep falling over so
don't get too crazy with it you know just give it give enough to give the
effect and it also might seem kind of counterintuitive that I paying this
black instead of white or yellow but remember that yellow and white even flat
white have a very hard time covering up things and this box had
some printing on it so it would have been hard for the white or the yellow to
cover it up so I just prefer to just do everything black unless there's a
specific reason that I'm painting it white and it's already a light color to
begin with I generally prefer to use the black so now all I'll get started on
this and show you how you do all right I'm ready together so I've
gotta already got a generous helping of yellow on my pallet and I have a fairly

so that it's not so thick yellow I'm gonna start hitting that now the idea of
the of the rubble is you want it to penetrate that remember you don't want
it to be like normal you don't want to look like it's got shadows you want the
yellow to be in the part that would be shadow and because the fire is a little
different you want it to look like it's glowing embers like it's lit from the
inside as opposed to shadows going in the border so it's kind of reverse
shading you want the lighter areas to be where it would be shaded and the darker
area is to be we're good
I'm just going to continue to cover this building with yellow and it doesn't have
